ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course taught me more about the process of reviewing grants, conflicts of interest, and searching scientific databases.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think this course contains a lot of very important topics that all physicians and scientists should be thinking about. I thought the speakers were all great. My only suggestion for improvement is that a lot of people in the class are going to be doing clinical research and need IRB approvals, etc.- but at these sessions it seems as though we only discuss cases relevant to people doing more bench research. I think it would be helpful to make the concepts more broadly applicable to the types of research the class is going to be engaged in.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: this course is a complete waste of time as a refresher course. a complete waste of time.

Yes- I definitely learned practical things in the course that no one has ever taken the time to teach more before (even though I've been doing research for many years)- such as the process of grant review and paper review, and different ethical conflicts that can arise in lab situations and what you should do about it. These are all things every scientist should know.
